issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.summary: Command to kill a YARN application does not work with newer Ubuntu versions

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.name: Open

issuetype.description: A task that needs to be done.
issuetype.name: Task

status.description: A patch for this issue has been uploaded to JIRA by a contributor.
status.name: Patch Available

fields.description:
This changed on Ubuntu 12.10 and later.  This prevents the kill command from executing correctly in Shell.java.

There is a bug filed in Ubuntu but there is not much activity. https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/coreutils/+bug/1077796
fields.summary: Latest Ubuntu (13.04)  /bin/kill parameter for process group requires a 'double dash kill -0 -- -<pid>

comments.body:
It works for me with Ubuntu 13.10:

jbonofre@vostro:~$ kill -1 -4175
jbonofre@vostro:~$ kill -1 -4341
bash: kill: (-4341) - No such process

So, I think that we can close this issue.

[~jb@nanthrax.net] can you please try /bin/kill.  kill is usually a built-in shell command and the built in command for Ubuntu works for me too (zsh and bash).  Additionally can you check /bin/kill --version. Mine is 'kill from procps-ng 3.3.3'.

Good catch Robert.

jbonofre@vostro:~$ /bin/kill -1 -34243
/bin/kill: invalid option -- '3'
...
jbonofre@vostro:~$ /bin/kill --version
kill from procps-ng 3.3.3

I checked with:
jbonofre@vostro:~$ which kill
/bin/kill

and the output confused me.

I gonna take a look on that to see if we can find a workaround that work with "all" kill commands.

This appears to be a bug in procps-ng based on http://www.freelists.org/post/procps/PATCH-33-kill-fix-PID-handling, and has been fixed in procps-ng-3.3.4 according to https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/coreutils/+bug/1077796.  I will download that version and test.

Downloaded 3.3.8 and tested the kill, seems to work
{noformat}
~/Downloads/procps-ng-3.3.8                                                             ⍉
▶ ps -ef  | grep rparker | grep sublime
rparker  10557  8903  0 18:05 pts/6    00:00:00 grep sublime
rparker  13541     1  0 Sep20 ?        00:00:09 /opt/sublime_text/sublime_text
rparker  13555 13541  0 Sep20 ?        00:00:00 /opt/sublime_text/plugin_host 13541

~/Downloads/procps-ng-3.3.8                                                              
▶ ./kill --version
lt-kill from procps-ng 3.3.8

~/Downloads/procps-ng-3.3.8                                                              
▶ ./kill -13541   

{noformat}

The patch works for me on Ubuntu 13.04.  I successfully issued a kill request that actually kills the application.  This is a very trivial change, so it would be nice if we could get it in the next release if it's verified to work on other linux versions.

Would be nice if we could fix the kill command in other places too.

org/apache/hadoop/mapreduce/util/ProcessTree.java
org/apache/hadoop/yarn/util/TestProcfsBasedProcessTree.java
By the way, the version I tried that worked was the 2.1.0-beta release version.
Any chance this can make it into 2.2.x?
I have run the 5 tests that failed on a Fedora VM and the tests all pass, but it does bother me that TestNodeManagerShutdown failed on the patch build.
firing the jenkins build again

I'm also affected by this issue on Google Compute Engine.
They are using Hadoop 2.4.1 with Debian GNU/Linux 7.8 (wheezy).

The log output looks like this
{code}
2015-03-05 16:51:39,570 DEBUG org.apache.hadoop.yarn.server.nodemanager.containermanager.launcher.ContainerLaunch: Sent signal SIGTERM to pid 27031 as user robert for container container_1425573565216_0002_02_000002, result=failed
{code}

The fix seems quite straightforward, the effects of such an issue are pretty annoying (resource leakage).
